name: Create a hook

params.name: name
params.description: Use `web` to create a webhook. To create a GitHub Service, use the name of a valid service. You can use [/hooks](https://api.github.com/hooks) for the list of valid service names. **Note:** GitHub Enterprise release 2.17 and higher will discontinue allowing admins to install GitHub Services. Please see the [Replacing GitHub Services guide](https://developer.github.com/enterprise/2.14/v3/guides/replacing-github-services) for details.

params.name: config
params.description: Key/value pairs to provide settings for this webhook. [These are defined below](https://developer.github.com/enterprise/2.14/v3/repos/hooks/#create-hook-config-params).

params.name: config.url
params.description: The URL to which the payloads will be delivered.

params.name: config.content_type
params.description: The media type used to serialize the payloads. Supported values include `json` and `form`. The default is `form`.

params.name: config.secret
params.description: If provided, the `secret` will be used as the `key` to generate the HMAC hex digest value in the [`X-Hub-Signature`](https://developer.github.com/enterprise/2.14/webhooks/#delivery-headers) header.

params.name: config.insecure_ssl
params.description: Determines whether the SSL certificate of the host for `url` will be verified when delivering payloads. Supported values include `0` (verification is performed) and `1` (verification is not performed). The default is `0`. **We strongly recommend not setting this to `1` as you are subject to man-in-the-middle and other attacks.**

params.name: events
params.description: Determines what [events](https://developer.github.com/enterprise/2.14/v3/activity/events/types/) the hook is triggered for.

params.name: active
params.description: Determines if notifications are sent when the webhook is triggered. Set to `true` to send notifications.

description:
Repositories can have multiple webhooks installed. Each webhook should have a unique `config`. Multiple webhooks can share the same `config` as long as those webhooks do not have any `events` that overlap.

**Note:** GitHub Enterprise release 2.17 and higher will discontinue allowing admins to install new GitHub Services, and existing services will stop working in GitHub Enterprise release 2.20 and higher. You can use the [Replacing GitHub Services guide](https://developer.github.com/enterprise/2.14/v3/guides/replacing-github-services) to help you update your services to webhooks.
